texts.definition: Depictions of game worlds that only contains the visual elements that are diegetically present.
markups: <style="Definition">Depictions of game worlds that only contains the visual elements that are diegetically present.</style>

Diegesis is the presentation of the elements in a game world. However, games may need to provide more information due to their systems containing more information than just the game worlds and when this occurs designers may need to question the value of having <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> or showing this information within the reference system of the game world.
<style="H3">Examples</style>

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Call%20of%20Cthulhu">Call of Cthulhu</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Storytelling%20System">Storytelling System</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/H%C3%A2rnmaster">Hârnmaster</link></style> can have <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> relatively easy since it is the game masters and players themselves that describe the world. Challenges to upholding this consistency can come when system terms (such as ''hit points'', ''character levels'', ''skill levels'', etc.) are mixed into the descriptions or when disagreements arise on what is actually part of the game world or not, or what actions are possible to do or not.

Diegetic Consistency is striven for in many Live Action Roleplaying Games given both the effort to produce the artifacts and props used in these and the effort in enacting bodily the characters and actions of these game (for several days in some case). Examples of LARPs that put especial focus on this, that can be said to aim at a 360 illusion, include 1942 – Noen å stole på and Trenne Byar. The related category of Alternate Reality Games, e.g. Prosopopeia and Conspiracy for Good also have this type of design aim.

<style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%202">Left 4 Dead 2</link></style> has a realism mode which increases the difficulty of the game by making the game have more <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style>; this is achieved by removing nearly all of the glowing outlines that help players locate other players and important game items even through walls.
<style="H2">Using the pattern</style>

While an obvious requirement for having <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> is that the design elements that represent <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style>, do not break the diegesis and theme, a more common problem with making <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> possible is to avoid <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-features">Non-Diegetic Features</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="extra-game-consequences">Extra-Game Consequences</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Extra-Game%20Information">Extra-Game Information</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="extra-game-input">Extra-Game Input</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="geospatial-game-widgets">Geospatial Game Widgets</link></style> (including <style="Link"><link="check-points">Check Points</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="ghosts">Ghosts</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="reward-widgets">Reward Widgets</link></style>), and <style="Link"><link="tooltips">Tooltips</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="hud-interfaces">HUD Interfaces</link></style> may be necessary to avoid as well, since they are not thematically consistent with all themes and are <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-features">Non-Diegetic Features</link></style> if an assumption existing that everything shown on a display should be presented the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="power-ups">Power-Ups</link></style> share similar problems but mainly since they so clearly affect gameplay. <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style>, e.g. <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style>, do not have to be presented within <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> but having them in any form may start making players perceive ''other'' game elements more from the perspective of a game system than a diegetic setting. For this reason, <style="Link"><link="game-state-overviews">Game State Overviews</link></style> in general work against <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style>. Related to this is having to do sequences of actions repeatedly, e.g. due to <style="Link"><link="setback-penalties">Setback Penalties</link></style>; this may not make diegetic sense. A second requirement is to not make to strong use of <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style> since they may be experienced as not being diegetic. <style="Link"><link="feelies">Feelies</link></style> can be seen as an exception to this claim, they provide physical <style="Link"><link="props">Props</link></style> that are <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style> but can even so expand the <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> beyond a game's primary medium.

<style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> can be easy to maintain during gameplay if <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style> are used to present <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>. This cannot be guaranteed in <style="Link"><link="self-facilitated-games">Self-Facilitated Games</link></style> but a solution, which puts the responsibility on somebody else, is to assign the task of portray <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> to <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>. While <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style> can create <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> since players can perform the expected actions, games using this pattern also create the requirement that ''all'' players should do so; this is even more the case for <style="Link"><link="physical-enactment">Physical Enactment</link></style>.

One part of designing for <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> is to make communication into <style="Link"><link="diegetic-communication">Diegetic Communication</link></style>, at least the communication that is in the diegesis. Related to this is the issue of <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-communication">Non-Diegetic Communication</link></style>: these may disrupt <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> but the risk of this may be mitigated by <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style> or by introducing <style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style>, especially in the form of <style="Link"><link="chat-channels">Chat Channels</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="emotes">Emotes</link></style>. Other options for avoiding <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-communication">Non-Diegetic Communication</link></style> include providing <style="Link"><link="prompting-techniques">Prompting Techniques</link></style> so players can communicate intentions about starting and stopping <style="Link"><link="scenes">Scenes</link></style> through diegetically consistent actions. <style="Link"><link="substitute-actions">Substitute Actions</link></style> is a technique to let players allegorically perform actions that would not be permissible otherwise and can thereby support <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> to a certain degree. <style="Link"><link="meta-postures">Meta-Postures</link></style> do the same thing but by introducing gestures or postures; these may not be consistency with the diegesis but can still make the break less obvious unless they are used to often. One form of <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-communication">Non-Diegetic Communication</link></style> is <style="Link"><link="reflective-communication">Reflective Communication</link></style> between players, so games with the design goal of <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> may be more difficult to create if they are to have <style="Link"><link="reflective-communication">Reflective Communication</link></style> also.

While <style="Link"><link="transport-routes">Transport Routes</link></style> can provide <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> by making it possible to access areas that should be able to access diegetically, one of the problems with providing <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> is related to size since thematically these should often be larger than is practically possible to design and implement. One solution, which risks breaking <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> instead, is to make use of <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="invisible-walls">Invisible Walls</link></style> since these can allow games to present an <style="Link"><link="illusion-open-space">Illusion of Open Space</link></style> and thereby larger <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> than are actually possible to visit. The use of <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> can be used separately or together with these since the <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style> can by having different themes and styles imply that not only intermediate areas exist but also others not yet seen. <style="Link"><link="warp-zones">Warp Zones</link></style> can be used to provide <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> when <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> do not have the same spatial characteristics as the medium in which they are presented in (a common example, found for example in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Civilization_(video_game)_series">Civilization</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Hearts%20of%20Iron%20series">Hearts of Iron series</link></style>, is to show spheres such as the Earth on 2-dimensional surfaces such as computer screens). However, they may also break <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> if the zones themselves are not part of the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> or if they point of other areas that are not part of the <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>.

While <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> is primarily about removing the presence of <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-features">Non-Diegetic Features</link></style>, not all parts of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> should actually be directly perceivable. This fact makes the use of <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="inventories">Inventories</link></style> help maintain <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style>. "Sticky" <style="Link"><link="switches">Switches</link></style> are related to this since they provide diegetic ways of showing states that otherwise should be hidden to maintain <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style>.

All <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> can offer challenges to <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> because of <style="Link"><link="early-leaving-players">Early Leaving Players</link></style>, but this becomes especially likely when they have <style="Link"><link="interruptibility">Interruptibility</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="drop-in-drop-out">Drop-In/Drop-Out</link></style> gameplay and the same applies to games with <style="Link"><link="seamful-gameplay">Seamful Gameplay</link></style>. In these cases the diegesis may need to be able to explain quick removals and/or returns of <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>, etc. under players' control. Similar problems exist in games with <style="Link"><link="entitled-players">Entitled Players</link></style> since here the players themselves may disrupt the <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> through how they use their abilities.

All games that have <style="Link"><link="dialogues">Dialogues</link></style> need to consider the <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> in these as well if the game as a whole is supposed to have <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style>.

<style="Link"><link="phasing">Phasing</link></style> is a pattern which by its definition breaks <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> but does so between players, i.e. individual players do not experience an inconsistency but may notice inconsistencies between their own diegesis and others if the player compare their gameplay experiences.

<style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> and <style="Link"><link="role-fulfillment">Role Fulfillment</link></style> can create each other. This since a presented <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> suggests <style="Link"><link="role-fulfillment">Role Fulfillment</link></style> goals to players in not breaking this consistency, and part of having <style="Link"><link="role-fulfillment">Role Fulfillment</link></style> experiences may be based on upholding this consistency.

While considering <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style>, it may be worthwhile to also consider <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="temporal-consistency">Temporal Consistency</link></style> since these also relate to the aesthetic experiences games can provide. It may for example be more important that the diegetic elements that exist in <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> behave thematically consistent to each other than that everything in the game environment is diegetically present. One area where <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> and <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> affect each other is creation of game objects in large worlds; the common diegetic requirement of game worlds be large creates thematic requirements of populating <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> with many game objects.
<style="H3">Diegetic Aspects</style>
<style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> is a completely diegetic pattern.
<style="H3">Interface Aspects</style>

The choice of <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> easily affects <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> - <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> can may maintain it while <style="Link"><link="god-fingers">God Fingers</link></style> break them. Controllable <style="Link"><link="cameras">Cameras</link></style> ''can'' break <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> even it they cannot be seen (an exception to this is found in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%2064">Super Mario 64</link></style> where the player's camera is diegetically presented and carried by the character ''Lakitu'') since moving into corner etc. can make the presence of these non-diegetic entities noticeable. Similarly, being able to invoke <style="Link"><link="game-pauses">Game Pauses</link></style> work against <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> when they make players enter <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style> (any <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style> can have problems with <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> as they often provide <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-features">Non-Diegetic Features</link></style>).

<style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> can be difficult to <style="Link"><link="player-character-awareness-consistency">Player/Character Awareness Consistency</link></style> since the latter may require or be most easily supported by <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-features">Non-Diegetic Features</link></style>.
<style="H3">Narrative Aspects</style>

Due to the <style="Link"><link="freedom-choice">Freedom of Choice</link></style> they give players, the possibility for them to engage in <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style> can make <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> break if non-diegetic elements are introduced; this is often mainly a potential problem in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>. In some games, this can be countered by letting players participate in <style="Link"><link="workshopping">Workshopping</link></style> technique before the game proper begins. As a more subtle issue, generic or repeated actions can be spotted by players as design elements more concerned with gameplay structures or game states, so modifying <style="Link"><link="agents">Agents</link></style> so their action are <style="Link"><link="context-dependent-reactions">Context Dependent Reactions</link></style> can be necessary to maintain <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> over time.
<style="H2">Consequences</style>

Having or not having <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> quite naturally affects how players perceive <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>. Having <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> is a requirement to be able to have <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> since any <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-features">Non-Diegetic Features</link></style> automatically also break a theme in the presentation of <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>.

Even if both <style="Link"><link="chat-channels">Chat</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style> may be motivated by <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> (<style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> should be able to talk to each other), the presentations of messages may disrupt the <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style>.

Since <style="Link"><link="live-action-roleplaying">Live Action Roleplaying</link></style> often tried to create complete and plausible physical environments in which gameplay can take place (especially in the Nordic tradition of <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Live%20Action%20Roleplaying%20Games">LARPs</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Diegetic Consistency</style> is often more important to these game than other to the point that the pattern modulate the possibilities of the <style="Link"><link="live-action-roleplaying">Live Action Roleplaying</link></style>. For games with <style="Link"><link="alternate-reality-gameplay">Alternate Reality Gameplay</link></style>, this is more or less a requirement since breakdowns in the diegesis reveal the game as a game; this is complicated by the fact that the game diegesis needs to be able to fit into the real world.
<style="H2">Relations</style>
<style="H3">Can Instantiate</style>

<style="Link"><link="alternate-reality-gameplay">Alternate Reality Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="role-fulfillment">Role Fulfillment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style>
<style="H3">Can Modulate</style>
<style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Game Worlds</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="live-action-roleplaying">Live Action Roleplaying</link></style>
<style="H3">Can Be Instantiated By</style>

<style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="abstract-player-constructs">Abstract Player Constructs</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="chat-channels">Chat Channels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="context-dependent-reactions">Context Dependent Reactions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="dedicated-game-facilitators">Dedicated Game Facilitators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetic-communication">Diegetic Communication</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="feelies">Feelies</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-masters">Game Masters</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="inaccessible-areas">Inaccessible Areas</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="inventories">Inventories</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="illusion-open-space">Illusion of Open Space</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="invisible-walls">Invisible Walls</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="levels">Levels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="meta-postures">Meta-Postures</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="physical-enactment">Physical Enactment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="prompting-techniques">Prompting Techniques</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="role-fulfillment">Role Fulfillment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="substitute-actions">Substitute Actions</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="switches">Switches</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tiles">Tiles</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="transport-routes">Transport Routes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="warp-zones">Warp Zones</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="workshopping">Workshopping</link></style>
<style="H3">Can Be Modulated By</style>
N/A
<style="H3">Possible Closure Effects</style>
N/A
<style="H3">Potentially Conflicting With</style>

<style="Link"><link="cameras">Cameras</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="chat-channels">Chat Channels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="check-points">Check Points</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="communication-channels">Communication Channels</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="early-leaving-players">Early Leaving Players</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="emotes">Emotes</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="enactment">Enactment</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="entitled-players">Entitled Players</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="extra-game-consequences">Extra-Game Consequences</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Extra-Game%20Information">Extra-Game Information</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="extra-game-input">Extra-Game Input</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="hud-interfaces">HUD Interfaces</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-features">Non-Diegetic Features</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="lives">Lives</link></style>, Widgets</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="roleplaying">Roleplaying</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="scores">Scores</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="seamful-gameplay">Seamful Gameplay</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="self-facilitated-games">Self-Facilitated Games</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="setback-penalties">Setback Penalties</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="storytelling">Storytelling</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tooltips">Tooltips</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="warp-zones">Warp Zones</link></style>

<style="Link"><link="interruptibility">Interruptibility</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="drop-in-drop-out">Drop-In/Drop-Out</link></style> in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style>
Games with <style="Link"><link="game-pauses">Game Pauses</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style>
